Designing and synthesizing metal-free and halogen-free Polyionic liquids (PILs) for heterogeneously catalyzing the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide is of great interest for CO2 fixation and high-value chemical production. Herein, three Polyionic liquids (PILs), named as [PDT1]-OH, [PDT2]-OH and [PDT3]-OH, are synthesized via a three-step procedure including free-radical polymerization of divinylbenzene and 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole, Quaternization with 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide and anion exchange of bromide anion with hydroxyl ion. These PILs are characterized using FT-IR spectroscopy, 13C CP/MAS NMR spectroscopy, XPS, FE-SEM, EDS mapping, TGA, nitrogen sorption isotherm, BET and BJH plot and CO2 adsorption isotherms. The newly synthesized metal-free [PDT2]-OH exhibits excellent catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition with Epichlorohydrin (ECH), resulting in 99 % ECH conversion with 98 % selectivity for chloropropene carbonate under mild reaction conditions (solvent-free, cocatalyst-free, 5 bar, 90 °C, 6 h). Moreover, this robust [PDT2]-OH affords versatility towards various epoxides and can be recycled for at least 5 consecutive cycles. The excellent catalytic performance of [PDT]-OH is attributed to the synergetic effect of multiple active sites, substrate activation through hydrogen bond donor groups, and efficient epoxide ring opening facilitated by in-situ generated bicarbonate ion (good nucleophile and leaving group) from hydroxyl groups. A comparative analysis with various reported catalysts predicts superior catalytic performance of the newly synthesized catalyst under metal-, halogen-, solvent- and co-catalyst-free conditions for CO2 conversion, highlighting its potential for industrial applications in CO2 fixation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co2 fixation Polyionic liquid Cycloaddition Cyclic carbonate Catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With rapid global industrialization, extensive CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion and automobiles pose a serious threat to the worldwide climate balance, significantly impacting the harmonious development of nature and humanity [1–3]. The atmospheric CO2 concentration, which was 280 ppm in the pre-industrial era (around the 1700s), has doubled to 427 ppm as of February 2025, as measured at Mauna Loa Observatory [4,5]. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) projects a 1.9 °C increase in the global mean temperature by 2100 if CO2 emissions continue at the current rate [6,7]. Controlling and reducing CO2 emissions is one of the greatest challenges of this decade, at least until renewable energies replace all carbon-based energy sources [8,9]. Achieving carbon peaking and neutrality is a globally recognized goal [10,11]. More importantly, CO2 offers intrinsic advantages including abundance, nontoxicity, non-flammability, renewability, and cost-efficiency. These qualities make it a crucial environment-friendly C1 chemical feedstock for carbon mitigation and sustainable development [12,13]. With advanced catalytic technology, CO2 can be utilized to produce various industrial chemicals and functional materials, such as formic acid, methane, methanol, urea, salicylic acid, carbon monoxide, polymers, and organic carbonates [14–20]. Generally, converting thermodynamically and kinetically stable carbon dioxide is an energy-intensive procedure. Therefore, using an energetic molecule, such as an epoxide, as a reaction substrate has proven to be a sustainable and promising pathway for efficient CO2 conversion [5]. The cycloaddition of CO2 with an epoxide ring produces a valuable 5-membered cyclic carbonate through a convenient, cost-effective, and atomically economic route (Scheme S2). Moreover, the biodegradable and non-toxic cyclic carbonate has diverse applications, including polymer synthesis, gas separation, electrochemistry, printing, dyeing, cosmetic and pharmaceutical industries [9,21]. Additionally, cyclic carbonates serve as high-boiling polar aprotic solvents and electrolytes in Li-ion batteries [22]. This CO2 conversion pathway not only adds value to industrial applications but also helps mitigate excessive CO2 emissions, contributing to atmospheric CO2 stabilization. To date, a wide range of homogeneous catalysts including ionic liquids, metal complexes, metal halides, and organic bases [23–25], as well as heterogeneous catalysts such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent organic frameworks (COFs), functional mesoporous silicones, metal oxides, and metal salts [26–29] have been explored for cyclic carbonate formation. Despite excellent catalytic efficiency, homogeneous catalytic systems pose challenges in product separation, often requiring energy-intensive distillation or solvent-consuming extraction for catalyst recovery, which hinders their further development [30]. To enhance recovery and recyclability while maintaining the catalytic activity of their homogeneous counterparts, heterogeneous catalytic systems have been developed. However, these catalysts also face critical challenges, including complex and costly preparation, metal and active site leaching, and limited catalytic efficiency [31]. Additionally, heterogeneous catalytic reactions often require halogen-containing co-catalysts such as tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), which can corrode equipment, pollute the environment, and pose human risks by accumulating in organisms [32]. Therefore, it is still highly desirable to develop metal-free, halogen-free, and highly stable heterogeneous catalysts for cycloaddition reactions for industrial applications. Ionic liquids (ILs) have emerged as a particularly attractive class of catalytic systems for the cycloaddition of CO₂ to epoxides, largely because of their excellent thermal and chemical stability, which allows them to operate under relatively harsh conditions without significant degradation. Their dual solubility for a wide range of inorganic salts as well as organic molecules further enhances their versatility in catalytic applications. In addition, the electrostatic interactions between the ionic species in ILs and the quadrupolar nature of CO₂ provide a favourable driving force for its adsorption and activation, while van der Waals interactions further stabilize the interaction between CO₂ molecules and the ionic framework [33,34]. These combined effects make ILs efficient for CO₂ capture and transformation. Nevertheless, despite these notable advantages, ILs are not free from limitations when considered for large-scale or continuous processes. One major issue is their hydrophilic behaviour, which can complicate the separation of products and recovery of the catalyst, thereby reducing process efficiency. Another critical drawback is their high viscosity, which restricts mass transfer and diffusion rates of both CO₂ and other reactants, ultimately lowering the overall reaction kinetics and catalytic turnover. These inherent shortcomings reduce their practical industrial utility, especially for processes requiring rapid conversion under mild conditions [35]. To address these drawbacks, significant efforts have been devoted to the polymerization of ILs into poly(ionic liquids) (PILs). By immobilizing ionic liquid moieties within a polymeric matrix, PILs combine the structural advantages of polymers with the functional versatility of ILs. The resulting materials exhibit a porous and heterogeneous framework that enables faster reagent diffusion, thereby minimizing the kinetic barriers imposed by viscosity [36–38]. At the same time, PILs possess high ionic density, adjustable porosity, broad structural diversity, and improved stability compared to their monomeric IL counterparts. Their tunable polymer backbones and functionalized ionic segments allow for tailoring of both physical and chemical properties, enabling the design of catalysts with optimized activity, selectivity, and recyclability. Furthermore, the presence of interconnected pores facilitates CO₂ uptake, while the ionic domains promote efficient activation of both CO₂ and epoxides, ultimately leading to enhanced catalytic performance. Thus, PILs offer a balanced combination of robustness, versatility, and efficiency, positioning them as a next-generation platform for CO₂ cycloaddition catalysis that successfully overcomes the inherent challenges of traditional IL systems. The synthetic approaches for preparing porous poly(ionic liquid)s (PILs) are generally divided into two broad strategies [39,40]; one is One-pot synthesis methods which involve direct polymerization or condensation reactions in which both the polymer backbone and the ionic liquid moieties are introduced simultaneously. Common techniques under this category include Free-radical (co)polymerization, Schiff base condensation, Click and Heck reactions, Friedel–Crafts alkylation, trimerization, and urea-forming reactions. Second is Post-synthetic functionalization where pre-formed porous polymer frameworks or supports are chemically modified by grafting ionic liquid moieties onto their surfaces. This method provides flexibility, as it allows careful control over the type and density of ionic groups introduced into the framework. One-pot strategies are especially advantageous because they ensure a uniform distribution of ionic liquid functionalities throughout the polymer matrix, while simultaneously achieving large surface areas and well-developed porosity. These features are crucial for enhancing the accessibility of active sites, thereby boosting catalytic efficiency. The first reported PIL for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with ethylene epoxide was synthesized by polymerizing 3‑butyl‑1-vinyl imidazolium chloride with divinylbenzene [41]. Subsequently, various imidazolium-based PILs were developed by crosslinking with polystyrene [42], divinyl benzene [43], and repeating CN bonds [44], incorporating different functionalized alkyl chains, such as amino [45], hydroxyl [46], and carboxylic groups [47]. These functional groups acting as hydrogen bond donors (HBDs) facilitate substrate polarization and stabilize intermediates through hydrogen bonding with the oxygen atom of the epoxide ring. The catalytic performance of these PILs follows the order: carboxylic group > hydroxyl group > amino group, based on hydrogen bonding capacity. Additionally, these studies incorporate various counterions, including halogens, hydroxyl groups, amino acids, BF4 -, and PF6 - to promote epoxide ring opening. Furthermore, the introduction of multi-center ionic liquid monomers bearing different numbers of substituents as cross-linking units into polymeric frameworks has proven to be an effective strategy for enhancing the density of catalytically active ionic sites. This design not only increases the number of accessible functional groups but also generates a more flexible and loosely packed network, which facilitates improved molecular diffusion during catalysis. In particular, the hexasubstituted benzene-based HDPIL, poly[PhSVIM]Br, demonstrated superior performance owing to the presence of six ionic substituents anchored onto the benzene ring [48]. Such a structural arrangement leads to the development of a highly open framework architecture, while simultaneously providing a uniform and dense distribution of ionic domains throughout the polymer matrix. These features significantly enhance CO₂ uptake capacity and epoxide activation, thereby contributing to higher catalytic activity and selectivity in the cycloaddition process. As discussed so far, vinyl imidazolium-based PILs have been widely reported. However, to the best of our knowledge, no studies have explored 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazolium-based PILs for CO2 conversion. Compared to vinyl imidazole, 1-Vinyl-1,2,4-triazole offers more active sites for CO2 adsorption, enhancing its CO2 adsorption capacity. Therefore, we investigated 1-vinyl-1,2,4-trizolium-based PILs for catalytic conversion of CO2 into cyclic carbonate. Mostly reported PILs have been synthesized by polymerizing ionic liquids with cross-linkers such as divinylbenzene. Liu et al. employed a solvothermal method to synthesize mesoporous PILs from non-ionic copolymers [49]. However, this approach requires an autoclave and involves harsh reaction conditions. In contrast, Dani et al. developed a milder procedure in which non-ionic vinyl imidazole was polymerized with divinylbenzene under mild conditions without using an autoclave, followed by ionization to form PIL [35]. This method allows for the introduction of different alkyl chains and counter ions with the same initial polymeric matrix, facilitating direct comparison and enabling the investigation of their effect on catalytic performance. In this study, we polymerized 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole with divinylbenzene to form a co-polymer backbone via free-radical polymerization using AIBN as an initiator. A series of copolymers is prepared by taking the monomers in different volume ratios to study the effect of monomer ratio on the catalytic performance of PILs. The co-polymers were ionized using an aliphatic alkylating reagent (2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide) to introduce ionic functionality, constituting a hydrogen donor group (amino group), followed by counterion exchange with hydroxyl ions to obtain desired PILs. The obtained PILs are metal-free, halogen-free, and heterogeneous systems that effectively catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide under mild conditions without any solvent or additive. The catalytic efficiency is attributed to the combined effect of excess active sites, hydrogen bond donor groups, and hydroxyl counterion during catalysis. These PILs catalyzed various epoxides efficiently, showing versatility. The catalyst was recovered by centrifugation from the reaction system, washed with dichloromethane and water, dried under vacuum, and reused for five consecutive cycles without significant change in catalytic performance. We also synthesized a previously reported vinyl imidazolium-based PIL [43] using the same synthetic route and analyzed its catalytic activity for the cycloaddition reaction for comparison with our novel PILs. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Divinylbenzene (DVB, 85 %), 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole (VTr, >97 %), 1-vinylimidazole (VIm, >99 %), 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide (99 %), Epichlorohydrin (>99 % (GC)), 1,2-Propylene oxide (>99 % (GC)), 1,2-Epoxybutane (>99 %), and Styrene oxide (97 %) were received from Sigma-Aldrich. α, α-azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN, 98 %), N, N-dimethylformamide (99 % (GC)), and Dichloromethane (99 % (GC)) were purchased from Central Drug House (CDH) (P) Ltd. Acetonitrile (>99 % (AR)), and Sodium hydroxide (97 % (ACS)) were obtained from Sisco Research Laboratory (SRL) Pvt. Ltd. All raw materials were utilized as received without any purification unless otherwise stated. Divinylbenzene that contained p‑tert-butylcatechol as an inhibitor for self-polymerization was treated with a 10 % sodium hydroxide solution so that the inhibitor was passed into the sodium hydroxide layer, and pure divinylbenzene was used for polymerisation. AIBN, a radical initiator, was recrystallised from methanol just before use. Carbon dioxide (CO2) was obtained from Super Gases, Sonipat. 2.2 Instrumental characterization Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded with KBr pellets on a PerkinElmer Spectrum Two model FT-IR spectrometer in the wavenumber range (4000–400 cm-1). 13C cross-polarization (CP)/Magic-angle-spinning (MAS) NMR spectra were collected using a JEOL JNM-ECX400II DELTA2_NMR spectrometer (9.38T) operating at 400 MHz. For recording the spectra, the Larmor frequency, the contact time, the recycle delay, and 90° pulse width were 100.5 MHz, 2 ms, 5 s and 4.8 µs, respectively and for reporting Chemical shifts, tetramethylsilane (TMS) was used as a reference. Elemental analysis was done on Thermo Scientific (Flash 2000) CHN Elemental Analyser (Thermo Finnigan) and under Eager Xperience software control in the analytical conditions of 1800 °C sample combustion temperature, 140 ml/min carrier flow, 100 ml/min reference flow, 250 ml/min oxygen flow, 5 s Oxygen Injection End time, 12 s Sample Delay time, 12 min Run time and 2–3 mg sample weight to determine the weight percent of specific atoms of carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and hydrogen (H) of all synthesized PILs. The surface elemental composition and bond energy of PILs were analyzed via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) studies on the Kratos AXIS SUPRA instrument using a monochromatic Al Kα (photon energy of 1486.6 eV) X-ray source. The surface morphology was investigated using a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM; 7610F/Plus/JEOL) operating at an accelerated voltage of 2 kV. Further, the elemental mapping studies were performed via an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscope attached to the FE-SEM instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on SDT Q600 within a temperature range of 25–600 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Nitrogen sorption isotherms of all the prepared PILs were measured on the BELSORP-maxII at −196 °C. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method (BJH) were used to calculate the surface area and pore size distribution of the PILs, respectively. Carbon dioxide (CO2) adsorption isotherms were acquired on Quantachrome Autosorb iQ at 273 K and 293 K. Before purging N2 or CO2, all samples were degassed at 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum. The catalytic performance ( % conversion and % selectivity for cyclic carbonates) was determined via proton-NMR (1H NMR) spectra using a Bruker Avance III-400 MHz spectrometer in CDCl3 solvent. 2.3 Typical procedure for the synthesis of polyionic liquids 2.3.1 Synthesis of non-ionic polymers A series of porous non-ionic co-polymers was synthesized via the radical polymerization method using monomers: divinylbenzene (DVB), and 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole (VTr) with AIBN initiator. A two-neck round-bottom flask was charged with monomers (as described hereinafter in entries 1–3, Table 1 ), AIBN initiator (10 % relative to the amount of the total monomers), and DMF solvent (30 ml), and the stirred reflux was conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere at 120 °C for 24 h. The copolymer was precipitated by transferring the reaction mixture to stirred water, filtered, and washed three times with acetone and water to remove unreacted monomers and solvent. The obtained solid was dried overnight in a vacuum. Homopolymers of divinylbenzene (Poly (DVB)), 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole (Poly (VTr)), and 1-vinylimidazole (Poly (VIm)) and a copolymer of divinylbenzene and 1-vinylimidazole (Poly (DVB-co-VIm), entry 4, Table 1) were also prepared via the same route for structure optimization. 2.3.2 Synthesis of polyionic liquids (PILs) 200 mg of the PDT1 (Poly (DVB-co-VTr)) and 800 mg of 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide were added to 20 ml acetonitrile. The reaction was heated and refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The suspension was hot-filtered, washed with acetonitrile, methanol, and deionized water sequentially, and dried for 24 h under vacuum. The obtained yellowish powder denoted as [PDT1]-Br, [PDT2]-Br, [PDT3]-Br, and [PDI2]-Br were prepared using the same procedure but replacing PDT1 with PDT2, PDT3, and PDI2, respectively. Finally, halogen-free Polyionic liquids were achieved via the ion-exchange method. The PIL-Br (0.5 g) was stirred in 100 mL 1 M aqueous sodium hydroxide solution for 72 h at room temperature. The solid was collected via centrifugation, washed with hot water until the pH of the filtrate reached 7.0, and dried overnight to get PIL-OH; [PDT1]-OH, [PDT2]-OH, [PDT3]-OH and [PDI2]-OH. 2.4 Catalytic performance of the PILs for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxide The catalytic performance of all prepared PILs was evaluated for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with various epoxides in a 25 ml high-pressure reactor. In a typical experiment, the epichlorohydrin and the catalyst (PILs) were placed in a high-pressure reactor that was sealed and purged three times with CO2 at room temperature to remove any impurities existing in the reactor. Next, the reaction conditions, the CO2 pressure (5–15 bar), the reaction temperature (50–110 °C), and the reaction time (2–10 h) were customized in the reactor. After the reaction completion, the temperature was cooled down, and the residual gas was discharged slowly. Finally, the resulting reaction mixture was filtered, and the reaction product and the catalyst were collected separately. The catalyst was washed with dichloromethane and water, dried and reused in the next run. The reaction product was analyzed by the 1H NMR spectrum, and % conversion and % selectivity for cyclic carbonate formation were calculated via the NMR integration method. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization A three-step synthetic procedure for Polyionic liquids ([PDT1]-OH, [PDT2]-OH and [PDT3]-OH) preparation was depicted: I) free-radical polymerization of co-monomers divinylbenzene (as cross-linking agent) and 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole (as functional monomer) taken in different volume ratio was performed to obtain copolymer with varying physicochemical properties in the presence of AIBN initiator. As a cross-linker, DVB provides a cross-linking hydrophobic framework leading to a heterogeneous character to the finally achieved catalyst, and 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole affords active sites for catalysis. The obtained copolymers were Poly (DVB-co-VTr)-2:8 (PDT1), Poly (DVB-co-VTr)-3:7 (PDT2), and Poly (DVB-co-VTr)-4:6 (PDT3) at a volume ratio of DVB: VTr of 2:8, 3:7 and 4:6, respectively, as shown in Scheme 1 . The loading of monomers in copolymers depends upon the reactivity of the monomers, as the dual polymerization functionality of DVB leads to a higher loading than others. Elemental analysis on all the non-ionic polymers was performed to determine the VTr loading in the copolymer, as shown in Table 2 . The results indicate that the N content and VTr loading increase in the same order as the initial feed ratio during polymerization; II) Quaternization of non-ionic copolymers was done with 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide forming ionic-copolymers; [PDT1]-Br, [PDT2]-Br and [PDT3]-Br as shown in Scheme 2 , confirmed by FTIR, EDX analysis, and XPS data; III) Anion exchange leads to improving the catalytic activity of the catalyst and also forming non-corrosive and halide-free Polyionic liquid. In particular, hydroxyl (OH-) anion was used to obtain [PDT1]-OH, [PDT2]-OH, and [PDT3]-OH (Scheme 2), where Elemental mapping and XPS analysis confirmed the complete anion exchange of the Polyionic liquids. No traces of bromide anions were remaining in [PDT]-OH. A similar three-step procedure was followed for the preparation of [PDI2]-OH, including free-radical copolymerization of DVB and 1-vinyl imidazole, followed by ionization with 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide and anion exchange with hydroxyl group (Scheme S1). All the prepared PILs were insoluble in almost all solvents, i.e., they afforded as heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxide. FT-IR spectroscopy was employed to illustrate the composition of homopolymers and all the co-polymers with different monomers volume ratios before and after the ionization step. The collected FT-IR spectra of homopolymers: Poly (DVB), Poly (VTr), and copolymer: PDT2 are compared in Fig. 1 (a), whereas Fig. 1(b) confirms the different compositions of all the synthesized copolymers with different volume ratio of monomers. In the spectrum of Poly (VTr) in Fig. 1(a), the transmission band between 2900–3100 cm-1 was assigned to -CHx stretching of both the VTr ring and the polymer backbone. These bands were somewhat overlapped by the sharp OH stretching adsorption band of the adsorbed water in Poly (VTr) showing highly hydrophilic characteristics of the Poly (VTr). The transmission bands at 1630, 1505, and 1205 cm-1 corresponded to C = C, C = N, and CN stretching of the triazole ring, respectively. The NN stretching and bending appeared in the spectra at 1275 and 1140 cm-1, respectively. The bands at 1385 and 1002 cm-1 were attributed to the -CH bending mode of the triazole ring. The out-of-plane (OOP) bending mode appeared at 665 cm-1. The absorption bands for -CHx stretching of Poly (DVB) were observed in the 2800–3100 cm-1 region in Fig. 1(a). The intense bands at 1660, 1600, and 1440 cm-1 were attributed to characteristic C = C stretching vibration of the benzene ring of Poly (DVB). Additionally, the bands at 900, 795, and 710 cm-1 were attributed to the out-of-plane (OOP) bending mode of the benzene ring. The appearance of absorption bands at 1505, 1275, 1205 and 1140 cm-1 confirmed the incorporation of the triazole ring, and the bands at 1660 and 1440 cm-1 proved the presence of the benzene ring of DVB in copolymer PDT2. In Fig. 1(b), the change in the intensity ratio of the specific transmission band of triazole and DVB confirmed the different compositions of the synthesized polymers. On moving from PDT1 to PDT3, the intensity ratio of triazole: DVB (1505:1440; 1002:795 and 665:710) bands decreased, indicating the highest amount of VTr ring in PDT1 that decreased towards PDT3. The ionization of copolymers, shown in Scheme 2, only perturbed the vibrational modes of VTr; the DVB modes remained almost the same, as shown in Fig. 1(c). A new peak appeared at 1385 cm-1 in all Polyionic liquids that were attributed to the aliphatic CNH2 stretching vibration of 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide, indicating the successful ionization of copolymers. After ionization, there was a slight shifting of the C = N stretching band towards a higher wavenumber as ionization enhanced the force constant of the C = N bond of the triazole ring. The peak for NH2 stretching overlapped with moisture adsorbed on the triazole moiety, which was difficult to distinguish. The anion exchange step exhibited no observable changes, except broadening of hydroxyl peak at 3400 cm-1. Solid-state 13C CP-MAS NMR spectroscopy determined the structure of Polyionic liquid ([PDT2]-OH), as shown in Fig. 2 . The presence of the characteristic peaks at 138 and 145 ppm corresponding to carbon atoms of the triazole ring and peaks at 116 and 128 ppm owing to the benzene ring confirmed the polymerization and incorporation of both triazole and DVB within the copolymer. The aliphatic carbon of the polymer backbone gathered between 10 and 50 ppm, and an intense peak at 48 ppm corresponding to ethylamine moiety proved successful ionisation, incorporation of 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide and formation of Polyionic liquid. The presence of peaks between 110 and 130 ppm for the benzene ring and 135 to 150 ppm for the imidazole ring in Fig. S1, signified the successful polymerization of 1-vinyl imidazole and DVB. Additionally, intense peaks at 48 ppm confirmed ionization and formation of Polyionic liquid [PDI2]-OH. The surface chemical composition of the copolymer before and after ionization and anion exchange was characterized by XPS analysis, as depicted in Fig. 3 . The survey scan spectra (Fig. 3(a)) revealed the presence of C, N, and O elements in all three samples, while [PDT2]-Br exhibited additional peaks corresponding to Br 3d, 3p, and 3 s. The presence of Br- peak in [PDT2]-Br signified the ionization of copolymer, PDT2, with 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide and further disappearance in [PDT2]-OH confirmed the complete anion exchange with the hydroxyl group. The Br 3d spectra (Fig. 3(b)) exhibited 2 peaks at 68.3 and 67.4 eV binding energies corresponding to Br-3d3/2 and Br-3d5/2, respectively. The survey scan showed a peak for O element in all three samples, but the comparative deconvoluted spectra of O 1 s (Fig. 3(c)) for PDT2 and [PDT2]-Br depicted 2 peaks at binding energies, 532.7/532.4 and 531.7/531.7 eV corresponding to adsorbed water and hydroxyl group of adsorbed water. However, O1s spectra of [PDT2]-OH deconvoluted into 3 peaks at 532.1, 531.9, and 531.2 eV, attributed to adsorbed water, OH- anion (after anion exchange) and hydroxyl group of adsorbed water, respectively. It is noteworthy that the chemically Oxygen element (OH- anion) is present only in [PDT2]-OH, whereas the oxygen source in PDT2 and [PDT2]-Br was adsorbed moisture. The N 1 s fitted spectra (Fig. 3(d)) showed 3 peaks at 401.2, 399.8 and 399.2 eV binding energies affiliated to NN(C)2, NN = C, and CN = C respectively in PDT2, whereas 4 peaks corresponding to -N+, NN(C)2, CNH2, and NN = C appeared for [PDT2]-Br and [PDT2]-OH both indicating successful ionization of PDT2. The deconvoluted C 1 s spectra (Fig. 3(e)) possessed peaks at binding energies 286.8, 285.6, and 284.4 eV attributed to sp2 hybridized carbon of triazole (NC = N), sp3 hybridized carbon of aliphatic amine (CN), and sp3 and sp2 hybridized carbon of benzene (CC & C = C) respectively. The survey scan spectra for the PDI2, [PDI2]-Br, and [PDI2]-OH shown in Fig. S2, depicted the successful ionisation of copolymer and further complete anion exchange with the hydroxyl group. The morphology of Polyionic liquids, [PDT2]-Br and [PDT2]-OH, was analyzed by FE-SEM. The FE-SEM images (Fig. 4 (a, b)) revealed irregular agglomerated grains with spongelike morphology and abundant porosity. This type of framework affords easily accessible active sites for the catalysis of the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides. A negligible effect was observed on the morphological features after the anion exchange, indicating stable networks. However, the anion exchange leads to fluffiness and enhanced porosity of the Polyionic liquids. In auxiliary with XPS analysis, elemental mapping (Fig. 4 (c, d)) data confirmed the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O, and Br in [PDT2]-Br and C, N and O in [PDT2]-OH, demonstrating the successful anion exchange of bromine with hydroxyl anions. Thermal stability of the Copolymers and Polyionic liquids were studied by TGA shown in Fig. 5 (a). All the copolymers show two steps degradation including drying stage where 3–5 % weight loss occur below 100 °C due to removal of moisture, and carbonization stage where decomposition of polymer backbone occurs above 400 °C. In Polyionic liquids three stages of degradation; Drying stage, Pyrolytic stage, and Carbonization stage observed. The initial weight loss (approx. 5 %) below 100 °C was due to adsorbed moisture. The second step weight loss (10–15 %) corresponded to the decomposition of ionic moieties (alkyl amine) increased from [PDT3]-OH to [PDT1]-OH, confirming the increment of triazolium moieties in Polyionic liquids. Degradation temperature decreased with increasing triazolium moieties, [PDT3]-OH: 236 °C > [PDT2]-OH: 220 °C > [PDT1]-OH: 180 °C. The final weight loss above 400 °C corresponded to the decomposition of the polymer backbone, similar to copolymers finally leading to the carbonization stage with char yield (approx. 40 %). The textural properties of PILs were analyzed according to N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm at 77 K and pore size distribution (Fig. 5 (b, c)). All the PILs exhibited type IV sorption isotherms (Fig. 5(b)) with hysteresis loops in the middle resembling type H3, signifying a mesoporous framework with heterogeneous pore distribution supported by the BJH pore size distribution curve (Fig. 5(c)). The random polymerization of 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole and DVB can be attributed to this heterogeneous behaviour. The BET surface area, pore size, and pore volume of all PILs are summarised in Table 3 . It is observed that increasing the volume ratio DVB: VTr enhanced the BET surface area due to a highly crosslinked framework [13]. To measure the CO2 affinity of the PILs, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were recorded within the relative pressure range of 0.0 to 1.0 bar at 273 K and 293 K temperature (Fig. 6 (a, b)). The adsorption capacity of all the PILs at 273 K outshines that of the PILs at 293 K, demonstrating an exothermic process. The CO2 uptake capacity of different PILs, summarized in Table 4 , followed the order: [PDT1]-OH > [PDT2]-OH > [PDI2]-OH > [PDT3]-OH at both 273 K and 293 K temperature and 1.0 bar pressure. This phenomenon could be associated with the availability of active sites for CO2 adsorption, i.e., the basicity of triazolic nitrogen, rather than the specific surface area of the catalysts. With increasing the volume ratio of DVB: VTr, the amount of triazolic basic nitrogen was reduced within the PILs backbone, which diminished the CO2 adsorption capacity. However, the surface area is cumulated in reverse order. [PDI2]-OH adsorbed CO2 more than [PDT3]-OH, which can be directly associated with a higher ratio of imidazole in [PDI2]-OH. 3.2 Catalytic screening for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide The catalytic screening of all the synthesized PILs was performed for the cycloaddition of CO2 with a benchmark substrate, Epichlorohydrin (ECH) under mild reaction conditions (90 °C, 5 bar CO2, 6 h and 300 mg catalyst) without any co-catalyst, solvent or other additives like halogens or metals etc. as shown in Table 5 . Notably, all PILs were insoluble in ECH, so the reaction is considered to happen in a heterogeneous environment. Despite higher ionic moieties of [PDT1]-OH, it exhibited 98 % conversion with 95 % selectivity for chloropropene carbonate (Table 5, entry 1) due to a small specific surface area, whereas, the lower catalytic activity (95 % conversion and 93 % selectivity) of [PDT3]-OH (Table 5, entry 3) with a large surface area was attributed to the low quantity of ionic moieties. [PDT2]-OH produced chloropropene carbonate with 99 % conversion and 98 % selectivity (Table 5, entry 2) due to the presence of higher active ionic moieties and a slightly larger specific surface area, as confirmed by 1H NMR (Fig. S3). The active sites including Lewis basic sites (Triazolic-N), nucleophilic groups (OH- moieties) and Hydrogen Bond Donor (HBD) sites (-NH2 groups) synergistically facilitated the adsorption of CO2 and activation of both ECH and CO2, whereas, large specific surface area afforded the availability of these active sites towards substrates for adsorption and catalysis. Specifically, -NH2 groups polarize the CO bond of ECH by interacting with the oxygen of the ring via Hydrogen bonding. Nucleophilic OH- promotes the ring opening by attacking the less sterically hindered β-C of the ring. Additionally, triazolic-N, OH- groups and -NH2 groups promote CO2 adsorption as Lewis basic sites. The results demonstrated that either a large surface area or higher active sites are not sufficient for better performance; the presence of both features and their synergistic contribution is a must. The analysis of [PDI2]-OH revealed lower catalytic activity (i.e., 85 % conversion with 89 % selectivity for chloropropene carbonate, Table 5, entry 4) under the same reaction conditions. Several factors that influence cycloaddition reactions, including catalyst loading, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure, and reaction time, are optimized for [PDT2]-OH due to its highest catalytic activity. Fig. 7 depicts the optimized results, including % conversion and % selectivity which were characterized via 1H NMR (Fig. 8 (a-d)) using the integration method as illustrated in the supplementary. It is worth mentioning that regardless of how the conditions are varied, high % selectivity is consistently achieved. Fig. 7(a) depicts the steady improvement in catalytic performance with increasing catalyst loadings. The % conversion and % selectivity for cyclic carbonate increased from 64 % to 99 % and 96 % to 98 %, respectively, with the enhancement of the catalyst loading from 100 mg to 300 mg. Further increasing the catalyst amount to 400 mg has a negligible effect on % conversion and % selectivity, as a sufficient number of active sites were already available with 300 mg loadings. The effect of temperature on % conversion and % selectivity is shown in Fig. 7(b). At 50 °C, the reaction achieved only 15 % conversion with 99 % selectivity for cyclic carbonate. However, as the temperature increased to 90 °C, the % conversion improved significantly to 99 %, with % selectivity reaching 98 %. Further elevation of temperature to 110 °C did not result in any substantial improvement in catalytic activity. It was determined that a reaction temperature of 90 °C would be the optimum choice, balancing energy savings and cost-effectiveness and avoiding unfavourable byproducts. Fig. 7(c) illustrates the effect of CO2 pressure on the conversion rate and selectivity of cyclic carbonate. Under controlled 1 bar gas pressure, a moderate conversion of 50 % with 97 % selectivity for cyclic carbonate was achieved, attributed to the insufficient molar amount of CO2. Increasing the CO2 pressure to 5 bar enhanced the catalytic performance, achieving 99 % conversion and 98 % selectivity. Further increasing the CO2 pressure to 10 bar and 15 bar reduced the percentage conversion while maintaining constant selectivity. This result was ascribed to mass transfer limitations as CO2 molecules become highly packed at high pressure, restricting effective interaction with the substrate epoxide and catalyst, thereby inhibiting the reaction rate. The time-dependent results for cyclic carbonate formation are presented in Fig. 7(d). After 2 h of reaction time, 57 % conversion was achieved with 97 % selectivity for cyclic carbonate. With a gradual increase in reaction time up to 6 h, the % conversion reached 99 % with 98 % selectivity. However, no significant improvement in catalytic efficiency was observed beyond 6 h, likely due to the nearly complete conversion of the substrate, ECH, to chloropropene carbonate (CPC). Based on these investigations, a catalyst loading of 300 mg, a temperature of 90 °C, a CO2 pressure of 5 bar and a reaction time of 6 h was identified as the optimum conditions for the efficient cycloaddition of CO2 with ECH. The catalytic performance of [PDT2]-OH was also investigated at atmospheric pressure using a CO2 balloon. The reaction was conducted with 110 mmol of ECH and 300 mg of [PDT2]-OH at 90 °C temperature under atmospheric pressure. After 12 h, a 62 % conversion with 96 % selectivity (Table 5, entry 5) for cyclic carbonate was observed, which increased to 98 % conversion and 98 % selectivity (Table 5, entry 6) within 24 h. The substrate flexibility of [PDT2]-OH in the cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxides has been investigated under optimised reaction conditions. The results were confirmed via 1H NMR spectra, illustrated in Fig. S3-S6 and summarised in Table 6 . The % conversion of epoxides varied depending on the presence of electron-withdrawing or electron-releasing groups and the nature of substrates, i.e., aliphatic or aromatic, while maintaining excellent selectivity for the corresponding cyclic carbonate. Epichlorohydrin exhibited excellent epoxide conversion (99 %) with 98 % selectivity for chloropropene carbonate (Table 6, entry 1), which is attributed to the presence of the electron-withdrawing group that facilitated the ring opening. The absence of an electron-withdrawing group in propylene epoxide reduced the % conversion. However, it still achieved 97 % conversion with 100 % selectivity for propylene carbonate (Table 6, entry 2) due to a small molecular size, which resulted in weak spatial site resistance. The % conversion for epoxy butane was further reduced (71 %, Table 6, entry 3) due to the presence of the electron-releasing group and its long aliphatic chain, which hindered mass transfer during catalysis. The aromatic substrate (styrene epoxide) exhibited steric hindrance to nucleophilic OH- attack during ring opening, resulting in only 55 % conversion (Table 6, entry 4). The heterogeneity, recyclability and structural stability of [PDT2]-OH were evaluated to ensure its potential for sustainable development and industrial application. After each run, [PDT2]-OH was easily recovered from the reaction mixture through centrifugation, confirming its heterogeneous nature. It was then washed with dichloromethane and water two to three times and dried at 70 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven before being used in the next catalytic run. Fig. 9 (a) illustrates a slight reduction in catalytic performance after 5 catalytic runs, with % conversion decreasing from 99 % to 93 % and % selectivity from 98 % to 95 %, indicating recyclability of [PDT2]-OH. This decline is primarily attributed to partial pore blockage during the catalytic cycle and unavoidable catalyst loss [50]. The structural stability, including composition and morphological properties, was evaluated by comparing FT-IR spectra and FE-SEM images of the five-times-used catalyst with fresh catalyst (Fig. 9). The FT-IR spectra in Fig. 9(b) indicated that all the characteristic peaks (triazole and benzene ring) were well preserved, with no significant changes in the recovered catalyst even after five catalytic runs, signifying the compositional stability of [PDT2]-OH. Furthermore, the FE-SEM image (Fig. 9(c)) of recycled [PDT2]-OH showed its morphological stability after reuse, confirming the good cyclic stability of [PDT2]-OH. Table 7 shows a comprehensive comparison of the catalytic performance of [PDT2]-OH with various reported excellent catalysts. Previous reports have achieved high epoxide conversion using the added solvents (Table 7, entries 1–3) or co-catalysts (Table 7, entries 4–5). The use of solvents and co-catalysts undoubtedly poses challenges in product separation, increases purification costs and may contribute to environmental pollution. Harsh reaction conditions, including high temperature and pressure, are typically required to efficiently convert ECH without solvents and co-catalysts (Table 7, entries 6–9). This significantly increases energy consumption and production costs. Extending the catalytic reaction time may allow lower temperature and pressure, however, it substantially reduces product efficiency (Table 7, entries 10–11). Some catalysts facilitate the cycloaddition of CO2 under ambient conditions but require large amounts of catalysts or extended reaction time (Table 7, entries 11–13). In contrast, in this study, we developed [PDT2]-OH, which not only eliminates the need for solvents and co-catalysts but also efficiently catalyses the cycloaddition of low-concentration CO2 with epoxide under relatively mild conditions (Table 7, entries 14–15), advancing environmentally friendly catalytic processes. 3.3 Calculation of activation energy for CO2 cycloaddition with epichlorohydrin The activation energy of the reaction has been estimated through a simplified calculation. Activation energy represents the minimum energy required for a molecule to transition from its ground state to a reactive state capable of undergoing chemical transformation. It can be viewed as the energy barrier that must be overcome for a reaction to proceed. For the cycloaddition of CO₂ with epichlorohydrin (ECH), the general rate law may be expressed as: (1) Rate = k⋅[ECH]a⋅[CO₂]b⋅[CAT]c Here, k is the rate constant, while [ECH], [CO₂], [CAT] are the concentrations of the epoxide, carbon dioxide, and catalyst, respectively, and a, b, and c represent their reaction orders. Since the concentration of catalyst and CO₂ remained essentially constant during the experiments (with CO₂ being continuously supplied), these terms can be combined into a single apparent rate constant (ka): (2) Rate = ka⋅[ECH]a where (3) ka = k⋅[CO₂]b⋅[CAT]c and (4) ln ka = ln k + b⋅ ln [CO₂] + c⋅ ln [CAT] According to the Law of Mass Action, the rate of the equation is: (5) Rate = −d[ECH]/dt For this system, assuming a pseudo-first-order dependence with respect to epoxide (a = 1) and combining Eq. (2) and (5), the rate law simplifies to: (6) −d[ECH]/dt = ka⋅[ECH] Integrating Eq. (6) gives: (7) −ln [ECH] = ka⋅t Eq. (7) can be written as Eq. (8) where x is the % conversion of ECH after t time period. (8) ln 1 ( 1 − X ) = k a · t From this relationship, the rate constant ka can be determined as the slope of the linear plot of ln [1/(1 − x)] versus reaction time t (Fig. 10 (a)). The ECH conversion at different temperatures is presented in Table S2. The excellent linearity of these plots confirms that the CO₂ cycloaddition follows first-order kinetics with respect to ECH. The temperature dependence of the rate constant is described by the Arrhenius equation: (9) k a = A · exp ( − E a R T ) Taking the natural logarithm of Eq. (9) (10) ln k a = − E a R T + ln A where Ea is the activation energy, A is the pre-exponential factor, R is the gas constant, and T is the absolute temperature. According to the Arrhenius equation plot (Fig. 10(b)), the activation energy for [PDT2-OH] is 57.13 KJ/mol. Based on current observations and previously reported mechanisms for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [12,43,62], a tentative mechanism is proposed for the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by [PDT2]-OH, as illustrated in Fig. 11 . Initially, both the alkyl amino groups on triazolium units (R-NH2) and the hydroxyl anions (OH-) act as basic sites, capturing CO2 to form carbamic acid (R-NHCOOH) and bicarbonate ion (HCO3 -) respectively. The carbamic acid functions as a strong hydrogen donor, while the bicarbonate ion exhibits excellent nucleophilicity and leaving group ability. The epoxide substrate is activated for the ring-opening by coordination of the oxygen atom of the epoxide with R-NHCOOH via the hydrogen bonding and polarization of the CO bond of the ring. Subsequently, the bicarbonate ion attacks the less sterically hindered carbon of the epoxide ring, facilitating this being the rate-determining step. The resulting oxyanion intermediate (III) is stabilized via hydrogen bonding with carbamic acid. Following this, CO2 inserts into the covalent CO bond, leading to the formation of a carbonate intermediate (IV). This intermediate finally undergoes a closed-loop ring closure reaction, yielding cyclic carbonate while regenerating [PDT2]-OH and HCO3 -. Thus, the presence of an amino-functionalized ionic liquid (IL) unit, along with a basic hydroxyl counterion in [PDT2]-OH, enhances CO2 affinity and facilitates nucleophilic attack for efficient ring opening. This synergistic effect contributes to superior catalytic activity under additive-free green conditions, highlighting its noteworthy potential for practical applications. 4 Conclusions A novel copolymer was synthesized by polymerizing 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole with divinylbenzene, followed by ionization using an alkylating agent, 2-bromoethylhydrobromide. The anion was then exchanged with hydroxyl groups to obtain porous multi-functionalized PILs via a simple green synthetic route. Various copolymers were prepared with different monomer ratios to evaluate their impact on catalytic performance. Among them, [PDT2]-OH exhibited optimal active sites and surface area, resulting in excellent catalytic activity (99 % conversion with 98 % selectivity) for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides under mild conditions- without requiring solvent, co-catalyst, or any other additive. This superior performance is attributed to the synergistic effects of multiple active sites, substrate activation through hydrogen bond donor groups, and efficient epoxide ring opening facilitated by in-situ generated bicarbonate ion (good nucleophile and leaving group) from hydroxyl groups. Furthermore, a comparative analysis of the synthesized 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazolium-based PILs with vinyl imidazolium-based PIL confirmed their high catalytic activity under identical conditions, owing to the presence of more active sites. The versatility and excellent recyclability of these PILs establish them as promising heterogeneous multifunctional catalysts for diverse applications, including CO2 conversion. coredata.dc:description: Designing and synthesizing metal-free and halogen-free Polyionic liquids (PILs) for heterogeneously catalyzing the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide is of great interest for CO2 fixation and high-value chemical production. Herein, three Polyionic liquids (PILs), named as [PDT1]-OH, [PDT2]-OH and [PDT3]-OH, are synthesized via a three-step procedure including free-radical polymerization of divinylbenzene and 1-vinyl-1,2,4-triazole, Quaternization with 2-bromoethylamine hydrobromide and anion exchange of bromide anion with hydroxyl ion. These PILs are characterized using FT-IR spectroscopy, 13C CP/MAS NMR spectroscopy, XPS, FE-SEM, EDS mapping, TGA, nitrogen sorption isotherm, BET and BJH plot and CO2 adsorption isotherms. The newly synthesized metal-free [PDT2]-OH exhibits excellent catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition with Epichlorohydrin (ECH), resulting in 99 % ECH conversion with 98 % selectivity for chloropropene carbonate under mild reaction conditions (solvent-free, cocatalyst-free, 5 bar, 90 °C, 6 h). Moreover, this robust [PDT2]-OH affords versatility towards various epoxides and can be recycled for at least 5 consecutive cycles. The excellent catalytic performance of [PDT]-OH is attributed to the synergetic effect of multiple active sites, substrate activation through hydrogen bond donor groups, and efficient epoxide ring opening facilitated by in-situ generated bicarbonate ion (good nucleophile and leaving group) from hydroxyl groups. A comparative analysis with various reported catalysts predicts superior catalytic performance of the newly synthesized catalyst under metal-, halogen-, solvent- and co-catalyst-free conditions for CO2 conversion, highlighting its potential for industrial applications in CO2 fixation.
